title: Wonnerup, Western Australia
text:
The townsite of Wonnerup is located south of <a href="Perth">Perth</a> and east of <a href="Busselton%2C%20Western%20Australia">Busselton</a>. It was gazetted a townsite in 1856, deriving its name from the nearby <a href="Vasse-Wonnerup%20Estuary">Wonnerup Inlet</a>.
The name is <a href="Aboriginal%20Australians">Aboriginal</a>, and has been shown on maps of the region since 1839. The meaning of the name is "place of the woman's digging or fighting stick"; the <a href="Noongar">Noongar</a> word for fighting stick is "wonna", while the suffix "<a href="-up">-up</a>" denotes "place of". The wonna was made from the peppermint tree, "<a href="Agonis%20flexuosa">Agonis flexuosa</a>", a coastal native found only in the south-west, and was a common trade item of the Noongar people.
The <a href="Wonnerup%20massacre">Wonnerup massacre</a> of Wardandi Noongar people by European settlers occurred in the vicinity of the area in 1841. The <a href="Ballaarat%20Tramline">Ballaarat Tramline</a>, Western Australia's first railway and railway bridge, was constructed in 1871 in the locality of Lockville, within Wonnerup. Wonnerup was later the junction of the <a href="Bunbury%2C%20Western%20Australia">Bunbury</a> to <a href="Busselton%2C%20Western%20Australia">Busselton</a> railway line and the <a href="Nannup%20Branch%20Railway">Nannup Branch Railway</a>. In 1998, part of Wonnerup was subsumed into the Busselton suburb of <a href="Geographe%2C%20Western%20Australia">Geographe</a>.
